reviewText: Here's the thing; this should have been amazing.  First you have the cast.  Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp are two of the most bankable stars in Hollywood, and they are both talented (albeit overrated, but talented).  They ooze this charisma that makes their actorly flaws seem irrelevant at times.  Then you have the director.  Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck has one other feature length film under his belt; 2006's Oscar winning film `The Lives of Others'.  That film is amazing and his directing of it was flawless (he should have been nominated in the directing category).  Then you have the story; a solid mix of action and mystery and you have that beautiful setting; Venice.None of it works.The setting, while beautiful, feels cheap.  The actors, while talented, lack any real chemistry and don't evoke any emotions.  Angelina relies on her fading good looks to keep us engaged and Depp tries to play quirky again and misfires.  Sadly, Paul Bettany has been further reduced to stereotypical `obstacle' and does absolutely nothing with the role (quick, Russell Crowe, come to his rescue).  The direction is also just standard and uninspired.  It felt like almost every frame was ripped from a better Cary Grant/Alfred Hitchcock collaboration.  The story had all the elements for a nice capper and yet it felt underdeveloped and stale.Angelina does nothing by pout her lips and smolder.  Depp does nothing but try to pull off ignorant.  Bettany does nothing by bark into the phone.I liked the twist at the end even if it felt too predictable (and nonsensical at that), but the construction of the film as a whole was a total mess.  I'm just so upset over this.  I really wanted von Donnersmarck to follow up his brilliant debut with something a little more profound, or at least a little more epic (considering the genre and stars he chose).  Instead, `The Tourist' feels too tepid and too insipid to matter in the slightest.  I think the funniest thing about this movie is the fact that the Globes nominated it in the Comedy category.  It's not funny (at least not intentionally).  It didn't deserve to be nominated for anything, but the fact that they changed the whole genre to fit their need to nominate big name stars is just hilarious.Skip this one.

reviewText: Angelina Jolie's appearance in "The Tourist" may someday set records for sheer photogenic appeal. She plays one of the most glamorous undercover agents ever to grace the silver screen; her wardrobe, her makeup, and her hair are all immaculate, and for some strange reason, they stay that way all 103 minutes of the film. Even when her character is roughed up by an odious mobster near the end, she still looks as if she has been prepped for a "Vanity Fair" photo shoot. This is, of course, a testament to her beauty as well as to the capable hands of her makeup artists, her hairdressers, and costume designer Colleen Atwood. Credit also to co-writer/director Florian Henkel von Donnersmarck for letting the camera linger on her face and figure a little longer than necessary. He clearly knew what the people wanted to see.But where does that leave the film itself? Is it supposed to be less about plot and more about serving as an extended fashion show? This is one of the few action thrillers that doesn't get away with being preposterous, for it doesn't have the conviction to go all out with it. Unlike Jolie's previous action film, "Salt," "The Tourist" is timid and flimsy. The stunts are never daring enough, the romance isn't passionate enough, and the sense of humor is so reserved that it seems completely out of place. The story is exceedingly simple, pretty much to the point that it barely holds our interest. Worst of all is the lack of onscreen chemistry between Jolie and costar Johnny Depp. The only real credit I can give it is for its beautiful cinematography and breathtaking scenery, the canals and Byzantine architecture of Venice shot with the same care and precision of an Italian tourism commercial.In the film, Jolie plays Elsie Clifton-Ward, a British beauty who cunningly misleads a federal investigation of her former lover, the unseen Alexander Pearce, a career criminal wanted in many countries by many people. This includes the heatless gangster Reginald Shaw (Steve Berkoff), who he embezzled billions from. Scotland Yard's Inspector John Acheson (Paul Bettany) has been keeping tabs on Elsie for two years in the desperate hope that she will lead them to Pearce; for reasons never adequately explained, he's driven to capture the elusive criminal and bring him to justice. Pearce stays in touch with Elsie through a series of handwritten notes, which are delivered in plain but neat white envelopes. Her latest instructions: Board a train from Paris to Venice, and along the way, throw off the authorities by seeking out and befriending a man with Pearce's height and build.Here enters Frank Tupelo (Depp), a nervous math teacher from Wisconsin hoping to forget a personal tragedy. He reads a spy novel. He puffs away on an electronic cigarette. He fumbles for his words like a man on his first blind date. Elsie regards Frank calmly, all the while calculating every move. They arrive in Venice. She convinces him to accompany her to a hotel and stay in her luxury suite - and, of course, he'll have to sleep on the sofa. In the aftermath of an intimate dinner and a few drinks, they kiss on the balcony. The next morning, while Elsie is out, a group of strange men barge into the suite intent on killing Frank, believing he's Pearce. And so begins the thriller portion of the film, highlighted by awkward action sequences, a contrived romance, and curious sudden appearances by Rufus Sewell. I leave it to you to discover whether or not his character is red herring."The Tourist," a remake of the French film "Anthony Zimmer," has all the reliable crime thriller clichés, including exotic locations, mobsters, a train ride, a mystery woman, and an apparent case of mistaken identity. It even has Timothy Dalton, although his role doesn't require him to be James Bond once again; he plays Chief Inspector Jones, who finds Acheson incredibly irritating and seems to take great pleasure in telling him off at the end. But even with all this at hand, something is missing. For something meant to be thrilling, we never quite go beyond the image of Johnny Depp running barefoot across loosely tiled Venetian rooftops. The blood never really pumps. The adrenaline never really rushes. It's all so flat and tired and insipid - not at all what I expected from a movie like this.There is, of course, an inevitable plot twist, one that surprised me by not being surprising. Perhaps that was shortsighted on my part. Considering everything that happens, considering what was said, considering what we're shown, could the film have ended any other way? Crime thrillers are constructed with the intention of misdirecting the audience before revealing the truth. What bothers me is that this movie makes no real effort to trick us; it leads to a conclusion that was obvious from the very start. With no good romantic subplot, with no decent action sequences, and with no engaging plot, what else is there? The more I think about "The Tourist," the more I return to its star, Angelina Jolie, whose beauty thoroughly overshadows everything else. That's not much of a compliment for the film itself, but it's the best I can do.
summary: He's Having an Identity Crisis, and She's Just Beautiful

reviewText: "The Tourist" is very similar to some of the Hollywood escapist fair of the 1950's and early 1960's with the likes of Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn and Grace Kelly. In several films during this era, Grant played an American in European exotic locales dealing with espionage in relatively light-hearted plots. The classic films of this ilk which come to mind are "To Catch a Thief", "Charade", even "Roman Holiday", taking place in Monte Carlo, Monaco, Paris, and Rome. In "The Tourist", Depp plays a Cary Grant-like character and Angelina Jolie has the long dark hair of Audrey Hepburn with the demureness of Grace Kelly. The action begins in Paris then moves to Venice.The best thing about the film in some ways is the opening. The viewer is plopped right into the middle of things without any background or knowledge. A demure mystery woman (Jolie) arrives at a café in Paris near the Champs-Elysees and orders something, which we learn is already being prepared. She's a regular. A mysterious note is given to her and provides detailed instructions concerning exact steps she's supposed to take right after leaving the café. While she is reading the note, we learn she is being staked out by some kind of government officials. Part of the instruction says "...pick someone with my height and build and make them believe it is me..." She burns the note and makes her way to the central train terminal in Paris.Part of the fun of the story is that we don't know who wrote the note, and part of the mystery-fantasy is a gradual revelation regarding who the unknown letter-writer is. (The voice-over for the note is Jolie, which is somewhat confusing at first.) On a train to Venice, she meets a clueless American tourist from Wisconsin, Frank, played by Johnny Depp. Depp (who doesn't exactly seem like a clueless tourist from Wisconsin) acts flattered that a woman who just walked out of Vogue Magazine would sit by him on the train. And so begins a rather fun, if somewhat improbable, misadventure. Depp appears to be someone "with my height and build". Two factions are on the trail on the unknown "letter-writer": Scotland Yard authorities who believe he has not paid back taxes on several billion British pounds, and an international mob run by an older baddie who would kill not only a man who cheats on his wife, but he'll kill his wife too, and all the members of both families. He would even kill the man's doctor, just for good measure. The mob boss lost billions to the mystery who was once a trusted part of his organization. Part of the plot is the tried-and-true "mistaken identity" device in which the authorities and the mob appear to be confusing the clueless tourist with the unseen letter-writer. Everyone is sure the man they want is Depp.A fun fantasy which combines elements of romantic-comedy and international espionage. The ending is pretty interesting, but there are aspects during the film which don't quite mesh with some of the scenes which have occurred previously. reviewText: By now nearly everyone has at least heard of The Tourist, the thriller that unites huge stars Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie. It's one of the movies that's probably on everyone's must-see list based on star power alone. The problem is that The Tourist lacks anything that would make it a memorable or worthwhile experience, which is disappointing considering who's involved.Federal agents have been following Elise (Jolie) for months as they wait for anything out of the routine to occur. The feds are after a man named Alexander Pierce, a man who Elise is known to be close with, that owes $744 million to the government. One day while tracking Elise, the unthinkable happens; something out of the ordinary finally occurs. What starts with a letter being delivered by a bike courier turns into a wild goose chase onto a train on its way to Venice. It's there that Elise chooses to sit next to a man named Frank (Depp), a math teacher who just so happens to be a tourist in Italy. As things progress, Elise constantly intervenes in Frank's plans and eventually draws him into her world where the federal agents begin to believe that Frank is Alexander Pierce since they have somehow never been able to get a clear look at his face. Frank is brought into the world of trickery and espionage, something that he's only read about in the spy novels he's so frequently caught reading. What began as nothing more than a stranger being picked out in a crowd slowly begins to culminate into a full fledged relationship that neither Frank or Elise can walk away from.When it comes to Angelina Jolie, her role is a bit different than some of her other recent roles. She seems to always play that strong female role that is either more than capable of taking care of herself or is just as strong as some of the bigger men in whatever project she's a part of. While that isn't necessarily a bad thing, it gets a little tiresome and you crave to see an actor do something outside of their range. While Elise is said to be able to take care of herself in The Tourist, we really never see any proof of that. She takes a life preserver and smashes it into a guy's face who's hanging off of a boat she's driving at one point, but that's it. The rest of the time she's walking around in elegant gowns and trying to look as feminine as possible. That and not display any sort of emotion whatsoever. This isn't what I had in mind when I wanted to see Angelina Jolie do something different.Johnny Depp doesn't have much room to talk either. While he's more than qualified to show emotional range or be incredibly eccentric at times, he seems to do nothing more than act like a watered down version of Jack Sparrow while doing the most idiotic and spontaneous things to put him in danger for a woman he's just met yet has become incredibly infatuated with. He does have a few one-liners that may get a chuckle or two, but they're delivered in such a flat tone that they'll probably be forgotten about once you leave the theater.The biggest joke about the film is the ending. It is literally so cliche and so atrocious that it makes the entire film a complete waste of time. Once it's revealed who Alexander Pierce is, you're left wondering if this entire string of events was really necessary. Imagine taking the longest and most dangerous route to doing something simple like making toast and that's pretty much how The Tourist goes about doing things. I could just walk to the refrigerator and get jelly or butter or to the pantry for peanut butter, but instead I'm going to lock my desired condiment in a safe, lead someone on a wild scavenger hunt all over the city that'll put them in harm's way, and make the government think that they owe them a massive amount of money so they run into problems with the law at every turn. That'll be fun, right? It'll make that toast taste so much better in the end, but the bread turns out to be stale and you just gag whenever you try to eat it since you've grown sick of having to swallow it so often.The Tourist is a stale thriller with flat performances from actors you'd expect a lot more from, but is still somewhat decent despite its flaws. I'm probably giving the film more credit than it deserves since I'm a fairly big fan of Johnny Depp and he was mildly enjoyable in small doses in this, but the film's ending pretty much destroys anything you may enjoy early on. It's just a shame since it had such potential to be a fun and entertaining thriller, but will probably still be mistaken for one because of the stellar cast alone.
summary: A dull, flat, and disappointing effort from Depp and Jolie

reviewText: The Tourist sets out to be a romantic mystery in the footsteps of Alfred Hitchcock.  Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp may not be 21st century versions of Grace Kelly and Cary Grant but a Jolie comes close being an ice princess. She is so impeccably dressed and poised that she deflects all emotion.Spoilers below.For me Angelina Jolie's character needed more of a past. We need to know to know that she has crossed the line from a Scotland Yard agent to compromising herself with Alexander Pierce.  Perhaps Inspector Acheson (Paul Bettany) should pick her up for questioning early in the film instead of Jolie walking into a police office to report after a year of saying nothing.Scotland Yard is motivated to capture Pierce because he owes the British government several million in taxes.  Since Pierce has stolen a huge amount a money from a crime boss one wonders where the taxes are coming from.  Pierce's character does not seem to warrant so much attention from the police. Maybe if he was also selling government secrets or had something that both the British government and the crime boss wanted there would be a more plausible reason for all the international fuss about capturing Pierce.There also is the problem that Jolie is not supposed to recognize Depp's Frank Tupelo as Pierce yet be drawn to him at the same time.  The lack of recognition places some distance between the characters at the conclusion when Jolie and Depp go off together it all seems abrupt. Unfortunately, Rufus Sewell doesn't get enough screen time as the phony Pierce to convince us that he might be the man everyone is searching for.End SpoilersThe Tourist has good performances by Paul Bettany, Jolie and Depp, but their performances were more on the average side than exceptional.  Steven Berkoff made a demented villain but I had some trouble taking him seriously.  For me, the backdrop of Paris and Venice gave the film its appeal.  Having Johnny Depp running across the rooftops of Venice in pajamas made the chase far more interesting.  The Tourist is interesting to watch, especially if you have an affection of Paris or Venice, but the story could have been thought out.

reviewText: In "The Tourist," director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck does his best to recreate the great suspense films of the late 50s.  Think Technicolor Hitchcock starring Cary Grant in "North By Northwest" or "To Catch a Thief" where the locale becomes a character and the plot relies on the whimsy and romantic persona of the lead male actor and his seemingly magnetic talent to attract primo women.  Perhaps, von Donnersmarck feels that Johnny Depp with his quirky ability to masquerade as a multitude of oddball personalities (Captain Jack Sparrow of thePirates of the Caribbean Collectionfranchise, Dean Corso inThe Ninth Gateand more recently The Mad Hatter inAlice in Wonderland) can emulate the insouciance and nerdy nonchalance of Roger Thornhill and John Robie, both Cary Grant creations.  If, additionally and in the same sense, Angelina Jolie can totter in the 4 inch heels of the mysterious fashionistas Grace Kelly and Eva Marie Saint with their knowing ability to manipulate their men and conquer their worlds effortlessly, the film would come together as both a homage and modern take on the classic thriller where through the error of mistaken identity, an average innocent person is hurtled into a life threatening situation that inevitably rocks his world romantically for the better."The Tourist" has all the right ingredients, but manages to fall short with perhaps too much editing and not enough background story.  The chemistry between the leads is meant to sizzle and relay to the audience just why one does anything for love.  However, some of the motivating factors are never spelled out or revealed with any anticipation or impact.  Sadly, the result seems a waste of talent and a film that doesn't intelligently scintillate as its advertising promises.In this case, Depp plays the innocent being led into the slaughter by femme fatale Jolie.  As with the Hitchcockian leads, their universe of espionage sparkles with the beauty of exotic locale--"Tourist" amply utilizes the Renaissance splendor of the Doge's Venice, scenes of luxurious hotels, glittering ballrooms and enchanted waterways as well as the elegant bustle of Paris where old world meets new at the immense Gare de Lyon for another classic innuendo-filled interlude on the TGV.  Grant and Kelly in a coupe on Monaco's famous hairpin turns are swapped for Depp and Jolie en water taxis traversing the canals of La Serenissima.  They all clean up nicely, donning tuxedos and gowns for the obligatory ballroom scene where the innocent has his "ah-ha" moment and accepts his new heroic role, cleverly driving the plot to its climatic scene and satisfying aftermath.Perhaps, director von Donnersmarck, feels that like the audiences of the 50s and early 60s, audiences today, tired of the austerity ensuing from financial insecurity, wish to return to an escapist genre of beautiful films featuring extravagantly dressed women and men with money to burn and an almost derogative nonchalance regarding its worth.  If this is so, to pull it all off more tightly, where the glitz of his locale and his two stars accent the story to perfection, he has a few things to reconsider.His leads must balance their elegance with a humanness that the audience feels and applauds.  Jolie is beautiful--her slim body draped in spectacular clothes that cause men and women both to stare unabashedly as she passes by like a reigning queen may seem a little overdone, but not completely unreasonable.  She is, after all, Angelina Jolie--so, why wouldn't we look?  As Elise, she doesn't speak much--just looks confidant, slinking through Paris and Venice, knowing full well wherever she goes she will be well received.  And, why not?  Nonetheless, despite this obvious perfection, when she taunts Depp with luminous eyes that suggest her struggle between the allegiance of career and the overwhelming tour de force that is love, she seems overly controlled--more a study of a woman in love rather than the actual being.  Jolie's performance aptly illustrates the difficulty to convey the rush associated with love and the ability to remain coolly elegant.Depp can be mischievously attractive--but Cary Grant he is not.  Jack Sparrow, yes.  But, he has his moments where the audience laughs out loud.  His jaunt across the Venice rooftops (again in homage to "To Catch a Thief") emulates Jack Sparrow slowly and comically sinking in his dinghy when we first lay eyes on him in the first of the Pirates of the Caribbean films.  However, in "Tourist" this farce of Depp in his PJs running for his life confuses rather than amuses.  Nonetheless, Depp as the archetypical Scamp charms us effortlessly; it is always a pleasure watching a good-looking man with a self-deprecating attitude win while in a situation with the odds stacked against him.  Depp doesn't have his usual crazy range to fall back on; he seems to be holding back--trying for restraint to not give too much away and unfortunately loosing too much of the whacky persona the audience wishes most to see.The secondary characters work better.  Paul Bettany and Timothy Dalton are both delicious as Scotland yard personnel. They blunder well while impeccably dressed, but other than the fact that as police on a case, the audience is not privy to the almost manic drive of Bettany to get his man.  The relationship between Bettany and his superior Dalton calls to mind Clousseau and Chief Inspector Dreyfus--even though "Tourist" thinks of itself as a different type of film when compared to Blake Edward'sThe Pink Panther Film Collection (The Pink Panther / A Shot in the Dark / Strikes Again / Revenge of / Trail of)series.But perhaps that is where Tourist fails.  Maybe it should be whackier.  Maybe Depp should have been allowed to channel a different type of innocent--one with Jack Sparrow's ruthless sense of humor and unconventional mores.  The hybrid nature of "Tourist" bewilders the audience into thinking something more is on its way that never quite arrives once the plot settles into the familiar ground that Hitchcock does way better.From the Hitchcockian standpoint, the storyline of "Tourist" may be a little weak with not enough moments between Jolie and Depp to make their more profound attraction more believable.  Think Eva Marie Saint, Cary Grant and that tunnel in North by Northwest. Whoa what a ride! Eva is on a mission, but she cannot help but be charmed.  In her attempt to be `the mystery woman,' Jolie seems to struggle a bit--trying too hard to be imperturbable, the audience does not always see her vulnerability and it wants to feel the chemistry. In this regard, the interlude on the train should have been more provocative, perhaps with some flashbacks to the Jolie character's affair with the infamous Alexander Pierce to show her confusion over her attraction to Depp and the allegiance she still feels for her lover.The city of Venice anoints the film with the benediction of its scintillating beauty and director of photographer, John Seale, can hardly ask for a better backdrop or assignment.  However, the city itself has mysteries of its own that could have been integrated into the story to make going to Venice less of a advertised travelogue and more the final destination culminating not only the Scotland Yard investigation, but the affair of the heart.  Somehow with more thought to the film's genre identity, as well as to the various factions of the story, the whole film would have benefited as a more adroitly crafted  entertainment.Bottom line?  "The Tourist" attempts to recreate the mood of the late 50s Hitchcockian thriller/romance with two attractive leads whose chemistry drives the action.  At the same time, some whacky moments intervene that suggest a tug towards the crazy comedy of the Pink Panther series.  Because this film does not know which genre it is trying to emulate, it fails on both levels.  Depp and Jolie try to pull it off by being beautiful people in the wondrous setting of Venice.  However, every once and a while, this reviewer wanted to see Depp in a madman's disguise--with that incredible braid in his beard and that twinkle in his eye.  Along those same lines, Beauty, as personified by Jolie, requires some chink in the amour of perfection--less polished tones and more passionate screaming.  Recommended nevertheless for its abundant display of the glories of Venice.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

reviewText: I get what director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck (The Lives of Others) is trying to achieve with this stylishly ludicrous 2010 romantic thriller. It's an homage to the glamorous movies that Stanley Donen directed back in the 1960's like Charade (Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn) andArabesque(Gregory Peck and Sophia Loren) which featured two attractive film stars at the peak of their allure in games of deception usually ensnared in an even bigger web of espionage. Perhaps because of his musical comedy background (Singin' in the Rain), Donen had a light touch that worked perfectly to set the tone of those classics. On the other hand, von Donnersmarck in only his second directorial effort displays a far more literal style that is anything but frothy, and sadly seems at odds with the soufflé touch this film badly needs to make it true escapist fare. He co-wrote the twisty, preposterous screenplay with two masters of the mystery genre, Christopher McQuarrie (The Usual Suspects) and Julian Fellowes (Gosford Park), and the film boasts the requisite star power with Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie.But something just doesn't feel right about the whole venture, and it may be a case of too many cooks in the kitchen waiting for their paychecks. Looking every inch the glamorous movie star, Jolie plays a mystery woman named Elise Ward who is being trailed by the French police working in cahoots with Scotland Yard. She receives a note from her former lover Alexander Pearce at a sidewalk café instructing her to take a train to Venice, find a stranger that looks just like him, and convince the police that the stranger is Pearce. Elise finds Pearce's doppelganger-to-be in Frank Tupelo, a meek math teacher from Wisconsin, and the chase begins in earnest as Elise reveals to Frank that Pearce stole two billion dollars from a surly gangster and is wanted for tax evasion by the police. The film feels like a series of heavily orchestrated set pieces meant to dazzle but only succeed in sputtering into incredulity, especially a sluggish boat chase in Venice's Grand Canal, the water of which looks ridiculously pristine. The ending is basically on par with Pam finding Bobby in the shower at the end of Season 8 ofDallasand just as convincing.Dressed to the nines by Colleen Atwood and immaculately made up, Jolie looks stunning and acts as best she can like she is the star of one of Donen's movies, but Depp is strangely at sea in his Cary Grant/Jimmy Stewart everyman role. Without a layer of makeup and his standard set of eccentricities, the actor flounders in an oddly blank-faced manner that makes Elise's attraction to Frank all the more puzzling despite his blind acts of puppy-dog devotion. A strong supporting cast has been assembled but given little to do beyond looking exasperated or confused - Paul Bettany as an inspector obsessed with capturing Pearce, Timothy Dalton as the chief inspector, Steven Berkoff as the merciless gangster, and Rufus Sewell as the mysterious stranger the police try to trail. reviewText: Starring Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp, The Tourist is romantic thriller/comedy from 2010.  The central lead is Elise (Jolie), who is being pursued while on the hunt for her lover Alexander Pearce, a man who is on the run after reportedly stealing big dollars from a gangster.  Elise teams up with the unsuspecting Frank (Depp), forcing her pursuers to think he is Pearce in disguise, only to spark a thrilling chase through Venice involving both police and gangsters, both of whom are desperate to catch Pearce.  But will Elise and Frank survive, and will Pearce eventually show up?In comparison to most modern thrillers, this is a slow-paced film, and not surprisingly it's been criticized by many for being devoid of action, and for lacking chemistry.  But what many perceive to be a weakness, I'd consider to be a strength.  The slow pace and apparent lifelessness seems to be a deliberate throwback to the older Hitchcock style thrillers, adding to the intrigue.  And while Jolie's persona comes across as cold and calculating (an effect maximized by excessive and immaculate makeup), it's her fidelity to Pearce that holds her back from Frank.  The respite from the usual sexual smut Hollywood is known for is welcome, and the amount of offensive material we're used to from contemporary thrillers is refreshingly absent for the most part, aside from a few instances of crude language.  It's true that the storyline lacks high octane action and special effects, but the romp through Venice is a visually pleasing one, and despite their cool interaction, the two protagonists keep the story moving and our curiosity aroused.My only criticism would be concerning the surprising twist in the storyline at the very end of the film.  On the one hand it's a very well orchestrated surprise, but it does make the actions and motives of one of the characters earlier in the film rather implausible.  But at the end of the day, we shouldn't be taking this too seriously anyway, but just enjoy the ride.  If you're up for something slower and are happy to avoid some of the more offensive material that usually plagues Hollywood, why don't you hop on board this tourist boat and head to Venice? - GODLY GADFLY
summary: A lazy holiday compared to other contemporary thrillers, but still a good ride

reviewText: THE TOURIST has many flaws, not the least of which is the fact that it doesn't seem to be able to make up its mind whether it is a suspense thriller, a romantic comedy, or a travelogue.  But despite all of its weaknesses, on the small screen in the home it comes across as an Italian delicacy well worth watching. Bouncing around from Paris to Scotland Yard and eventually to serenissima Venice the visuals (thanks to cinematographer John Seale's ability to capture the flavors of Venice so beautifully) steal the show. The story written by none other than Julian Fellowes ('Gosford Park', 'Separate Lies',  'Young Victoria', 'Vanity Fair', 'From Time to Time') with director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, Christopher McQuarrie, and Jérme Salle (whose 2005 French thriller 'Anthony Zimmer' spawned this American version) is quirky by entertaining, and the musical score by James Newton Howard adds distinction to the film.Elise Clifton-Ward (Angelina Jolie, dressed to the nines and looking like a mannequin) is on a mission: she is being closely followed on secret video by Scotland Yard Inspector John Acheson (Paul Bettany) and Chief Inspector Jones (Timothy Dalton) who expect her to meet up with one Alexander Pearce and gain back the money stolen from crime lord Reginald Shaw (Steven Berkoff). She eludes capture and boards a train to Venice where her instructions from Pearce suggest that she meet a man who looks like Pearce.  Interpol is engaged and the Italian police - led by Sergente Cerato (the extraordinarily handsome Alessio Boni) et al - pickup the chase for Scotland yard.  On the train Elise meets American spy-fiction fan and math teacher Frank Tupelo (Johnny Depp) and manipulates his emotions and attention to the point that Frank follows Elise to Venice - and the mystery thickens. Amid interesting characters are 'The Englishman' (Rufus Sewell) and Conte Filippo Gaggia (the ultimate Italian leading man Raoul Bova, remembered for his important role in 'Under the Tuscan Sun') who add to the suspense and incidents of mistaken identity.  To say anything further would rob the viewer of what little suspense the script contains.The very fine cast seems to be sleepwalking through much of the story, but they are still so terrific to watch that they make the film a fine evening's entertainment.  Probably this film is better on DVD than it was one the big screen in theaters: the story seems more intimate and the relationships more credible.  Grady Harp, March 11
summary: A Thin Storyline Successfully Disguised by Gorgeous Cinematography

reviewText: Don't expect a deep moral, ethical, political or religious meaning in this film. It is not an author's film , as they say in Paris. It is first of all a remake of the eternal Arsène Lupin or Rouletabille to remain French, or simpler Robin Hood to turn English, or William Wallace to lean towards Scotland. And definitely I am fascinated by these thieves who steal the money of the very rich for their own sake, with a few crumbs to the poorest. And here the very rich are Russian, making fortunes in casinos and brothels, so it is just right to steal billions of decent currencies from them, though it is bad to forget paying one's income tax to the British Treasury.The film is simple but effective. We kind of know from the very start who Alexander Pierce may be, but that's not important at all because what is essential is how that thief who nicely put several billions of some good currencies in his pocket directly from the coffers of a Russian Mafioso, will evade the police and escape from the real Russian gangsters.There is no depth in all that but there is a lot of fun and action. It is also so realistically critical of the world's polices that it turns funny somewhere. The English police are only interested in recuperating the income tax that was not paid. The French police are whipping other cats, as they say in French, and looking the other way. The Italian police are only attracted by the profit they can make out of selling their prisoners to the highest bidder. Only Interpol, or a couple of Interpol agents are honest, though some might already be too high a count. Only one in fact and as long as the game is funny and paid for by his authorities.The most difficult part is to convince the girlfriend that she is just doing what she has to do, according to the letters he has delivered to her regularly when there is a bend or turn along the way. Ha has spent one million dollars having his own face restructured somewhere in Brazil, or Latin America, and she does not know what he looks like any more. She is an Interpol agent and he can count on her being able to resist anything including violence and her being very creative in her actions. And she does not disappoint us, and probably not our Alexander Pierce.While she is going from one station to the next according to his instructions, he is getting close to her and observing her and getting the protection she can get from Interpol who are protecting and following her, just like a pack of dogs would follow the smell of a fox. In fact the scent is that of a vixen in this case since Interpol, or the Russian gangster do not know the scent of the fox since he has spent a fortune to change his physical parameters.And everyone will be happy. The Russian Mafiosi will be all dead, as dead as a bunch of door nails, though not enough nails to nail down their coffins. The British cops will recuperate the 744 million pounds of overdue tax money they wanted to get out of the business. The beautiful Elise will be reunited to her mysterious Alexander Pierce. Alexander Pierce will be able to sail away with no one on his tracks any more.That's a pure action film done in the best immoral tradition of the morality one can find in robbing the rich. It is their fault any way. They would not be robbed if they were not rich. Let them give everything away and follow Jesus on his way to Capharnaüm or Jerusalem. Unluckily today's rich people are not like the tax collector Matthew. They don't believe in giving their money away and they prefer losing their lives rather than not retaliating against some one who borrowed a few billions from their coffers with the intention of not bringing them back. There is a Zorro in the heart of every good citizen.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU
summary: Which one do you prefer, Ribin Hood or Zorro?

reviewText: Some may applaud Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's efforts to direct a film which ushers the viewer to a more sophisticated era of filmmaking.  A time with Cary Grant, Audrey Hepburn, and Grace Kelly.  Ultimately, however, the boring dialogue, the predictable ending, the mediocre performance from the two leads, and the jumbled direction/screenplay - is this a thriller, a romance, or a comedy? - turned this into a messy James Bond imitation, with nowhere near the suspense or seductiveness.  There is neither legitimate espionage misdirection nor substantive comedy.French police are in cooperation with various agencies on the trail of the beautiful Elise Ward (Jolie).  They conspicuously follow her from her home to a local coffee shop where she appears to be dressed for a ball and boringly orders the exact same item in the exact same chair as she always does.  The chase begins after a mysterious note from someone named Alexander Pearce gets hand-delivered to a perpetually blasé Elise.  Apparently the snobbish attitude leached aboard the British accent.  Aboard a train she soon meets American math teacher Frank Tupelo (Depp), who proceeds to legitimately bore everyone within a 3-mile radius for the foreseeable future.The cast roll-call is outstanding, but it says something that nobody could outshine either of the disappointing leads.  Paul Bettany and Timothy Dalton play Police Inspectors, the former because he needs the roles and the latter because of subtle one-upmanship.  Steven Berkoff is [insert name of generic bland guy].  Rufus Sewell is namelessly and insignificantly inserted.  Weighed, measured, and found wanting.So what could possibly be left?  Unlike the movies it portends to imitate, The Tourist is nothing more than the films from which it wishes to separate: CGI and visually dominated films bereft of realistic plot or competent dialogue.  This film is nothing more than beautiful landscapes and the looks of its two stars.  In that regard, Depp often looks disheveled and uninteresting, and Jolie, despite the fact that she's dolled up from into to credits, is not nearly as interesting as all the other characters seem to think she is.This film serves as nothing more than a Venice tourism promotion and for Angelina Jolie's Google image search hit count.Jason Elin

reviewText: The Tourist is the 2010 English-language debut from director Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, who previously directed the highly acclaimed German filmThe Lives of Others. Sporting a cast lead by two of the biggest movie stars in the world, the movie opened to mostly negative reviews and mixed audience reaction. After seeing this movie twice, I think the negativity is somewhat misguided. It's not a great movie, simply a fun piece of mindless entertainment that never takes itself too seriously. Apparently, this movie's light-heartedness and mindlessness is lost on audiences who think every film is meant to be taken seriously unless there's an explosion every few minutes.Angelina Jolie plays Elise Clifton-Ward, a beautiful woman being followed by the police in Paris as they attempt to apprehend Alexander Pearce, her former lover. Pearce stole two billion dollars from a gangster named Reginald Shaw (Steven Berkoff) and is wanted by Shaw for this transgression and by the authorities for tax evasion. Elise receives a letter from Alexander that directs her to board a train to Venice and find someone of his height and build to mislead the police. Obliging him, she boards the train and meets Frank (Johnny Depp), an everyman schoolteacher. While the police quickly realize that Frank is not Pearce, mistaken identity puts Shaw on Frank's trail. The movie co-stars Paul Bettany as the lead investigator of the case Inspector John Acheson and former James Bond star Timothy Dalton as Chief Inspector Jones.While I too have found flaws, there are several things The Tourist does right. Shot in Venice, the locale is beautiful and cinematographer John Seale gives the film a beautiful, elegant look. Of course, discussing this movie and elegance it would be a sin not to mention Jolie who all but seethes elegance the moment she enters the frame. Jolie's performance as Elise has been accused of being "stiff," which is a criticism I highly disagree with. This is not a role that requires her to conjure up great emotional depth. Elise is a glamorous, mysterious woman and Jolie captures that perfectly. While Jolie looks like the glamorous movie star she is, Depp is rugged enough to be convincing as the empathetic everyman and he basically steals every scene he's in. Depp is a quirky, inventive actor who can usually find an interesting character attribute to toy with. As Frank, he's playing a wholly average man who is immediately in awe of Elise and the situation she's dragged him into. Depp is clearly having fun with this role and the way he tackles it makes it immediately fun to watch. His everyman shtick is not without a unique charm that only Depp could provide. His one-word reaction to seeing Jolie at the hotel for example is priceless.Criticism has also been aimed at the perceived lack of chemistry between Depp and Jolie. How is it possible that two of Hollywood's biggest movie stars could not have chemistry together? Well, I found that they DO but it's not Bogart/Bacall-type chemistry but more of a stilted, awkward one. This is entirely appropriate as Frank is in awe of the fact that a woman like Elise would even talk to him. Towards the end of the film, the two transcend that initial awkwardness and develop a convincing romantic dynamic. It's a cute chemistry that Depp and Jolie share, just not one for the history books.The Tourist was marketed as an action-comedy and has elements of both, but is more of a throwback to films that give plot a backseat to beautiful movie stars and a beautiful locale. Von Donnersmarck is an acclaimed director whose last film was a pretty heavy drama and it seems obvious that this film was an excuse to go to a beautiful place and have fun. It's obvious that the actors involved had the same intentions. This is not a movie that's meant to be taken seriously and if you watch this movie under the impression that it's Oscar-bait, then a lot of elements would seem poorly executed. If it's not apparent from Depp's performance alone that this is just a fun, light-hearted romp then you need to watch more movies. Even the action/chase/Depp-in-peril sequences are fun and light-hearted, without being too heavy on the suspense.With all of that in mind, even as the light-hearted romp it is, there are both mild criticisms and serious flaws present in The Tourist. For a film with beautiful cinematography and production design, the score by James Newton Howard, while not bad by any means, is rather typical of a European espionage film. The music just lingers listlessly in the background, rarely making itself noticeable. The biggest flaw here is the final twist; a twist so forced and contrived that it insults the film that came before it and fails on no less than two levels. The first is that it is completely devoid of logic, it makes no sense, and it betrays nearly all the characterization that came before it. If you watch the film aware of the twist, you realize that a particular character is either incredibly stupid, forgetful, or just blissfully unaware of the twist that directly involves him. Few movies have an ending that seem more tacked on than this one. Even worse, the script is co-written by Christopher McQuarrie, the Oscar-winning scribe behind The Usual Suspects. The twist at the end is already unoriginal and something that we've seen many times before but the fact that McQuarrie, in a shameless act of self-plagiarism, was responsible for writing it simply adds insult to injury. This is obviously a major problem, but beyond that I have little to gripe about.The Tourist is light entertainment that aspires to be nothing more than that. I think everyone involved succeeded at making the film they intended to make and, for what it's worth, they did a commendable job. If not for the twist that insults both the film and the people watching it, it could be much better. There is nothing particularly memorable or fresh about this movie, but it is much more breezy and enjoyable than the critics would have you believe. If you're in a mood where you feel the film Knight & Day will be too taxing on your mental energy, The Tourist is exactly the breezy entertainment you're looking for.GRADE: B-

reviewText: Angelina Jolie stars as Elise, an alluring and mysterious woman whose every move is being watched by Interpol. reviewText: I had to see this movie to answer the obvious question: If you put Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp in a movie together, do you get a really good movie or a really bad one? Evidently, you get a really bad one.The whole thing is about A.J.'s thickly-lacquered face with its over-inflated lips gliding along - either when she's ambulating down the street or floating by in a motorboat. Let's just say she doesn't show a lot of range. She never - not once - changes her expression. The entire part could have been portrayed by a life mask made of epoxy, and fitted with slowly batting eye-shadowed lids.If the woman were in some sense beautiful, this might all have worked, but she isn't beautiful in this movie. If the camera is framing her face, she looks artificial to other-worldly. If it zooms back a little, she looks skinny. If the camera zooms back a little more, she looks ridiculous, because she is so thin, her shoes look way too big. It's worth mentioning that A.J. shows no skin in this movie, probably because she is so emaciated that if she did, the only thing she would arouse would be concern.Once again, it IS very important to analyze how A.J. looks in this thing, because that's the only thing this movie is about. (Some actresses come out with lines of cosmetics. A.J. should come out with a line of Alkyd enamel.)No matter how good the actor, each has a default role he can do in his sleep and usually does. Johnny Depp has one - the one in this movie. That's all that need be said about him.The villains are all Russian - except for the lead villain. He is actually British but LOOKS Russian, and (so it is explained) hangs out with Russians. So why isn't he Russian? Dunno. Have to guess the actor couldn't do the accent. Why are the others Russian? Don't know that one either. Russian villains are cliché and so is the movie, so maybe they're just being decorous.All the Russians are ugly; the American is hapless; all the male Brits but the villain who couldn't do the accent are dashing; Jolie, who was raised in Britain, is supposed to be beautiful, but misses the mark.There have been some references to the predictable plot twist. I suppose you can call it a twist - albeit one that requires torque wrench. It was still predictable, but only because the movie was so bad that one could not possibly rule it out.As others have noted, _The Tourist_ could have been done differently in the forties or fifties, with a script built around leads that had personality and chemistry. It would still have been a trifling affair, and a cliché, but it would have been entertaining. This movie comes off like _Xanadu_'s attempt at a musical. The idea was there, the concept was straightforward, but the producing, directing, and acting skills to pull it off were lost in the intervening decades.This attempt is simply incompetent.

reviewText: Based on the French film "Anthony Zimmer" this movie is about a thief who is trying to reignite a romance with a woman he left for two years.  With a new face, a new voice, and a new name, he lures the woman to Venice where he plans to reveal himself and explain his long absence. The mistaken identity angle is intriguing, the scenes of Venice are spectacular, and the music is great.  "The Tourist" isn't perfect.  As I said Depp and Jolie never really connect as a romantic pair, and the ending is a little flat.  In an effort to make her glamorous, they put so much makeup on Jolie that she looks like a department store mannequin.  They could have wiped most of it off and she would be more beautiful.  With that said, "The Tourist" is a beautifully photographed movie, with great cast of characters, and enough intrigue to keep the plot moving.  I suggest watching "The Tourist" and "Anthony Zimmer" together, and enjoying how the same story can be told in such different ways.

reviewText: I enjoyed The Tourist. It's not a life changing, Oscar worthy movie, but was something interesting to pass the time. I particularly enjoyed the ending. It was a nice surprise and I smiled and thought "that's cute." I have no idea what it's genre is though. I don't see it as a comedy (doesn't have a lot of laughs), not a drama, not a thriller (nothing thrilling about it), not adventure, not action (there's no action except a bland running away scene), romance? Could be, but there's really no romance between the two characters. They kiss probably 3 times and there's really no passion or intimacy.As most have said, yes the scenery is gorgeous, stunning. The hotel Jolie and Depp stay in is beautiful. Seeing it all makes you wish you could be like this Alexander Pierce that everyone is after, with his stolen billions, so you can live in breathtaking Italy.On to the flaws--the actors. Jolie is my favourtie modern actress. She's original, unique, different and I consider her one of the most beautiful women on earth--when she had on weight. In her last few movies for the past few years, she's unattractively skinny. She's not the take-your-breath-away beauty anymore, and it's because she's so damn skinny. Besides from her alarming and unsettling appearance, she's very stiff in this, and doesn't show much emotion. She swishes around in heavy makeup, long hair needing a cut, and dresses I actually consider ugly. There's a scene where she's very Audrey Hepburn with her dark sunglasses and pearls, and was the one outfit I liked, but they didn't show enough of her in that scene.Non-emotion goes for Depp as well. I felt he played his part even worse than Jolie. What the hell is up with Depp in this movie?! HIM, not his character, seems slow, lethargic, bored, out of his element. He plays it with no force or vigor. He has a little interest in playing his character but just not enough. The face expressions are there, but the energy and movement aren't (Bad guys are running after him, and he's scared, his face shows it a bit, but there's nothing within projecting). His face is also bloated, old, and unattractive. Seeing him "normal", you see that he's short and petite in stature. I don't consider JD ugly, but never swooned over him or saw him as sexy. This movie solidifies that he does nothing for me. But I've always aloofly admired him and his movies; the fact he chose to play oddball characters, instead of the the action hero or the hot guy. Some reviewers have answered my question about what's wrong with Depp, and I agree with them that it's because he's only comfortable playing eccentric characters. For him to be normal, is to be a walking corpse, basically. Jolie has more range and can be different characters while still being "very Angelina" in each.The supporting actors give much better performances. Bettany gets an A for giving his best to be the lead detective. The only other I consider lifeless like Jolie and Depp, is the bad guy Alexander stole from. Who they refer to as the "gangster." He's not intimidating at all and seems to be acting just to receive the paycheck.All in all, watch this movie if you want to be transported to a beautiful mediterranean country called Italy, and would like to be entertained with a charming story about identity. Not for those that seek action, hate lighthearted, fluffy movies of the '50's and '60's, or require great acting from the actors.

reviewText: How my ratings work:5 - I really liked/loved it4 - I liked it3 - Could've been better/worth a look2 - Just didn't live up to the potential1 - Simply awfulEven though I felt this movie had potential, I just can't give it more than one star. This movie is a mess. I get that it was trying to capture the feel of a 60's romantic thriller, like Charade, but it fails miserably. As my review title says, go watch Charade instead. Audrey Hepburn and Cary Grant were two of the most glamourous stars of their time. Hepburn was beautiful and when it came to fashion was one of the most stylish women around. Cary Grant was suave and super cool, it's easy to see anyone falling for his charms. I'd love it if they'd just release this movie theaters. They used to do that more often, but now you can only see an older movie in theaters if you're lucky enough to have a theater that plays them. I don't think I really need to go into the plot of this movie, there are plenty out there and of course there was the trailer for it as well. I recall this movie got a lot of promotions and even had giant cardboard displays at theaters. And why not, it stars two of the biggest actors today, Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie.This part is gonna stir up some controversy because of what I'm about to say; I'm not a fan of Angelina Jolie. I've never seen the hype of her as an actress. And this has nothing to do with the whole Jennifer Aniston/Brad Pitt thing; Hollywood has plenty of this kind of drama going on that it's nothing new. I admit I enjoyed her in Girl, Interrupted, she did a great job in that movie as well as the rest of the cast. In fact her earlier work is way better given that she did riskier roles compared to now. Just about every role she takes on is just very standard Hollywood, and when she was first getting big she was doing all kinds of unconventional roles. I recommend seeing the movie Gia where she plays a drug addicted model, it's a sad movie (based on a true story as well) but it's well made and acted. I also enjoy her in the Kung Fu Panda movies, although the major highlights of those movies come from the action and comedy. But in a way those movies go with her conventional roles of playing a tough as nails women like in Lara Croft or Wanted. So yes, she's done some good movies here and there. But for the most part, she's just meh. She rarely does a lot of emoting in movies, and giving a cold stare the whole time doesn't mean you're acting and giving any real depth. And sure I can see that she's an attractive woman, but not so much in recent years. She's started getting way too thin. And in terms of acting, her other half Brad Pitt is way better and has done some more interesting roles. This movie doesn't help with her looks either. There's the heavy makeup she's wearing and she looks silly with her attempt at a sexy walk. Really I'd say Girl, Interrupted was her last real daring role where she showed off some raw emotion and showed that she can act. But most of the things she does now are just her looking pretty, or trying to be a bad@$$. Now I still need to see some of her newer films. I haven't seen Changeling yet, but my main reason for wanting to see that is because it's directed by Clint Eastwood, who is really good at working with actors and getting them to give a decent performance.As for Johnny Depp, I love the guy. He has a natural charm for sure. Yes in recent years he too has done more standard roles as well. But he at least still entertains me with these performances; Captain Jack Sparrow has become one of my favorite movie characters. And even in more standard films he seems to at least be putting in some effort, more than I can say for Jolie in most things. Not so much in this movie though. I'd say he was doing it for the paycheck. There's a quote by Jolie that she was just doing because she thought hey it'll be a quick shoot and she had nothing better to do. That's the secondary problem with this movie too. Neither are really putting effort in their performances. I can't really buy Depp as a simple math teacher; Depp has no business playing a normal person. His most normal performance was probably the original Nightmare on Elm Street, and that was a supernatural slasher film where he got sucked into a bed followed by a geyser of blood. The other would probably be What's Eating Gilbert Grape, but even in that he was part of dysfunctional family and surrounded by eccentrics. See both movies if you haven't, they're classics.The primary problem with this movie is that it's predictable. Even from the trailer it was super obvious that Depp's character was going to be this international thief, otherwise it wouldn't be exciting enough. If you're star is Depp, of course he's going to be the suspect. Course this movie fails to be exciting as everything moves slowly. I'm guessing the $100 million budget was mainly because Jolie and Depp cost a lot of money. Course I'm sure Paul Bettany and Timothy Dalton weren't cheap either. I've seen more exciting, fast paced action films that didn't cost nearly this much. The 2006 actioner Shoot 'Em Up cost $39 million to make, that's more than half of what this movie cost. Look at the first Terminator movie, it only cost $6 million. Sure it's sequel cost $100 million, BUT that movie was fast paced and awesome! The 2003 Italian Job cost $60 million and was more exciting than this; sure it wasn't a fantastic movie but it was at least fun. This movie spends most of it's time wanting to show off the Venice. Sure Venice looks great, but this is supposed to be a thriller with some action and such. It doesn't deliver very well on that. The George Clooney film The American (released the same year) cost $20 million and had some stunning Italy landscapes, and it's pace was slow too, but it did it in a way that was able to still build tension and have some mystery to it. Now I can see the American dividing opinions, but I'll still stand by what I said when I think it has a more engaging plot. Since the twist of the Tourist is obvious, it just leaves you thinking of when they're finally going to reveal when Depp finally admits he's the prime suspect. If he and Jolie had chemistry and actually put effort into their performances I could ignore that because I'd least be entertained. But they don't, and it just gets really tedious. Going back to Charade, certain things were obvious, but again it had a great pace and Hepburn and Grant had excellent chemistry and used their charms. But Depp just looks bored. Say what you will about any of the Pirates sequels, but at least then you can tell he's having a good time in those movies. Also those movies used their budgets well to give us some mind blowing special effects and awesome action scenes (the whirlpool fight in World's End is EPIC!) and the rest of the cast I'm sure see he's having fun so they try to have fun. This movie though isn't fun though, another thing that Charade has above this movie. Most of the cast seems to be trying, but it really isn't enough if your leads can't wake up and do some acting.That's really all I have to say. Hope I didn't ramble on too long. While this may not be super informative of the movie itself, I hope it at least entertained and I've managed to get people to watch the other movies I talked about. Seriously, any one of those movies is a lot more fun that this one.

reviewText: I just saw this movie in the theatre. It's a wonderful, escapist, fun filled ride through romance and adventure. It's what going to the cinema is supposed to be about.Most of the criticisms of the movie seem to be from people who don't understand or appreciate the genre. There's not a lot of sex scenes, gore or 3D special effects. Instead, the film makers have tried to keep our attention by using plot, humour, lavish cinematography, the beautiful Venice as a backdrop, and the stylish, star qualities of the leads in Jolie and Depp.The movie is a throw back to the romantic adventures of the 50s. I believe it is a remake of an older film. I enjoyed it in a similar fashion to The Thomas Crown Affair, which is also a remake of an older film.Some critics have complained that Jolie appeared a bit stiff in this role. I disagree. She was larger than life in elegance and sexiness, and that's the whole point in making the movie. Some people just don't get it. I can guarantee that most men won't be taking their eyes off her even when other characters enter the scene.Jolie plays a British goverment agent who's in love with the major league criminal that everyone else is looking for.[As an aside] Jolie's character's name is Elise Clifton-Ward. This is an inescapable reference to the character, Penelope Creighton-Ward, who was also a British secret agent in The Thunderbirds TV series from the 1960s.Americans won't know much about The Thunderbirds, but Brits, Australians and probably some others know Lady Penelope Creighton-Ward from this hugely successful kids TV adventure series that we all grew up loving. Penelope (and all the other charcters) were played by wooden marionettes.This may explain why Jolie sometimes appears a little wooden.So I would personally like to thank Angelina, her make-up and costume artists, and all the makers of this film for bringing this daring and beautiful secret service agent truly to life. She was stunning.Go and see this movie and treat yourself to a fun night out.

reviewText: The shallow merits of The Tourist do little to remedy its paper-thin characterization, forgettable score, mismatched actors, and chronic identity crisis.  It is appropriately titled, however, in that the plot was no doubt contrived on a $14 coffee coaster in San Marco while the cast 'toured' Venice. The drum and French poodle were all that was missing.  Furthermore, the unremarkable script was saturated with clichés and predictable eventualities, which conspired to poison the already non-existent chemistry between Depp and Jolie.  Even worse, the attempted blend of comedy, espionage, and Summertime(esque) romance only cannibalized its individual components and added to the confusion.  The effect was glitz and kitsch, not glamour and thrill.  The film also failed to showcase those subtle elements that make Venice the most awe-inspiringly romantic city in the world.  The result is a "cinematic experience" that utilized for its backgrounds shop-bought Venetian postcards.To be fair, there were a few witty lines like the "ravenous/ravishing" pre-dinner exchange.  Good stuff.  Had they been faithful to this lighthearted, comedic prescription and axed the absurd spy vs. spy subplot, the movie would have been more memorable.  Ironically, Timothy Dalton's minor role--owing to his ageless appearance and former work as 007--seemed to steal the show.If you're in the mood for a believable romance that truly captures the essence/charm of Venice, go rent David Lean's Summertime, starring Katherine Hepburn and Rossano Brazzi.

reviewText: "The Tourist" was made with the best of intentions, there is no denying that. Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck's ode to Alfred Hitchcock'sTo Catch a Thief (The Centennial Collection)is breezy, charming entertainment. The story here may seem pat on the surface, and upon it's initial viewing the ending may come out of left field for some. But be sure to pay attention because everything does add up. By design you will not be able to fully appreciate Elise (Angelina Jolie) and Frank's (Johnny Depp) romantic relationship, which is a major part of the film, the first go around. It's in that narrative hurdle that many will be turned off by the film or worse, dismiss it all together once it ends, but like I said, a second viewing will certainly clear things up and even make it much more enjoyable. The chemistry between Jolie and Depp is, much like the film, light as a feather. This is something that can also be counted as a detractor but I thought it worked quite well. Films of this style need a breezy air about them and Jolie and Depp easily bring that to the table. In the end "The Tourist" is misunderstood and underrated. I think many contemporary film goers just aren't familiar with 1950s European romantic mysteries like "To Catch a Thief" making it nearly impossible for them to properly gage "The Tourist." If you are aware of this style "The Tourist" will be a light, fun diversion. It's nothing special but it's certainly nice to see that they tried.

reviewText: This is a nice throwback to classic spy, mystery, thriller, romance films of the 1960s.  Don't expect any frenetic car chases with fast-cut editing here.  This is all about picture-perfect settings, elegant women, and subtle dialogue that creates a sophisticated look and feel within the wonderful European charm that is Venice.Angelina Jolie is perfectly cast as a mysterious woman who oozes charm and seduction with every glance of her eye and subtle sway of her hips.  Scotland Yard and other European authorities are following her in hopes of finding a thief who has stolen a great deal of money.  Johnny Depp is a hapless tourist who through a chance meeting gets caught up in her web of activities and people tracking her.The plot takes some small twists and turns that keep the viewer guessing a bit as to how things will turn out.  There is great cinematography amidst the wondrous canals of Venice, and no camera could love Jolie more than in this film.  Depp is drawn to her as a moth to the proverbial flame, and no man could blame him.The movie falls short of a high level of excellence probably because of weaknesses in the script.  There were no glaring flaws exactly, but there were no clear strengths either beyond the basic concept.  However, the other film elements make up for this to create a fine escape with plenty of charm and eye candy from the settings and the personas of Jolie and Depp.  It's a nice tribute to an older style of European mystery-thriller and romantic-comedy filmmaking with a strong cast of modern actors in both the lead and supporting roles.

reviewText: The stars of this movie are Angelina Jolie's poise and stature and her big smokey-brown eyes and the beautiful Venice locale.  Johnny Depp is no Carey Grant and underplays his role as the titular tourist; this movie doesn't do anything to add to his stardom (and it certainly wouldn't be thrusting him toward stardom if he weren't already a movie star).  Angelina gets the far better role here.  There are a couple of twists of course (one in the middle that I didn't see coming and the one at the end that was pretty easy to see ahead of time--but I won't ruin either of them here).  For me the most interesting character was Paul Bettany's Inspector who was WASPish in his desire to capture the film's "villain" and whose tone-on frustration in being repeatedly thwarted or overruled at every turn was a delight to watch.
summary: "The Tourist" is an accessible, if not rich, travel diversion.

reviewText: "The Tourist," a Hollywood remake of a 2005 French film "Anthony Zimmer," is not just a thriller. With Angelina Jolie and Johnny Depp both top-billed, "The Tourist" also wants to be a romance, and even a comedy, too. Whatever the film may be, one thing is certain. "The Tourist" is a beautiful film to look at, but not much else beyond its surface.Johnny Depp is an American tourist Frank Tupelo, a math teacher on board the train heading to Venice. A beautiful, femme fatale-like woman Elise approaches to him and apparently Elise has been followed by men in suit. With two talented players and a beautiful Venice backdrop, "The Tourist" could have been a hugely entertaining suspense (or romantic / comedy suspense). Sadly, Florian Henckel von Donnersmarck, director of Oscar-winning "The Lives of Others," seems not to know what he is making at all.Some may say people shouldn't take "The Tourist" too seriously. We know we shouldn't. The film was inexplicably nominated for three Golden Globes including Best Picture: Musical or Comedy category. Certainly it is mildly amusing watching Johnny Depp in pajama trotting on the rooftop, but the joke wears out its welcome really fast as the lengthy scene goes on and on.Who is "Alexander Pearce" and what did he do? Why a gangster Shaw (Steven Berkoff, wasted) is after him? I am not sure whether the film is really trying to be a thriller, or just mocking the conventions of the genre. Whichever it is, with a paper-thin story and one-dimensional characters (and half-hearted acting from the leads), frankly we don't care.
summary: (2.5 STARS) Beautiful to Look at, But Not Much Else

reviewText: Most likely this movie will work for true fans of film from the 1950's and 1960's.  The Tourist harkens back to a time when stories were presented as a sophisticated genre.  What?  No instant answers?  No blood and flames and explosions?  You have to be engaged with not only the senses but also the brain to fully enjoy this hat tip to an earlier era of film-making.To set some information straight about the characters, Jolie's character is named Elise - not Elsie.  Depp plays his role of bumbling traveler to a T and Rufus Sewell adds a thread of mystery that has you guessing.If you haven't watched many foreign or Hitchcock suspense films set in the jet-set locals of Europe or been enamored by the slow pace of The Day of the Jackal, then you may find this film out of synch with your typical expectations.  This film is rich with scenery, fashion, wealth, and low key twisty intrigue.  What it lacks compared to today's heavy handedness of a Borne Identity type film is exactly what makes this refreshing.  The cinematography is stellar.The best:  Lush backgrounds and lean, well dressed characters with a higher level of vocabulary than the typical language du jour of most recent films.  The worst:  Probably too slow paced for the run of the mill viewer.  The in-between:  Drop the expectations of a Hollywood cookie cutter film adrenaline high and be entertained by the locale, the language, and the intrigue.This is worth seeing if you are a serious film buff.

reviewText: When my wife said she wanted to watch The Tourist, I actually thought that Owen Steinhauer's  The Tourist , a book I reviewed, was made into a movie.  So I expected a serious movie, full of darkness and intrigue, about a spy acting like a tourist to accomplish his assignments in foreign countries.  This is not that movie.  Instead, it is a romantic comedy involving an actual tourist mistaken as a much sought after thief.The Tourist is a action adventure romantic tale staring Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie.  Both Depp and Jolie have performed well in action suspense tales before and the experience shows.  Jolie has appeared in romantic films, and this may be one her better presentations.  In this movie reoccurring bits of humor are excellent, like Depp trying to escape bad guys without shoes, in his pajamas, running across rooftops in Venice.  This film is full of action and intrigue, but much of the action is slightly funny - like bad guys, on foot,  trying to catch a boat in Venice.Johnny Depp does an excellent job portraying Frank, a mild mannered Wisconsin math teacher on vacation in Europe.  His interaction with Jolie, a sophisticated beauty who is obviously at home in the best restaurants and shops, is especially noteworthy.  Depp easily conveniences me that he is nearly a "Casper milktoast".  Jolie, who plays the sophisticated Elise, clearly portraits the knowing rich girl who is aware she is constantly being watched but provides an attitude so confident that everyone places her at the center of their attention.The actions scenes are believable and exciting.  The settings are exquisite, both in the hotels and restaurants, and on the streets of Venice.My wife and I both enjoyed this film.  I recommend it for a pleasant evening..
